reviewText:
Product received for free

This game is a match the tiles kind of game, similar to Candy Crush, Chuzzle, Bejewelled etc. However, there's one thing that's different - when you match a minimum of three tiles you summon a unit, the icons on the tile represent a type of unit, you can summon two units by matching 4 tiles, 3 by matching 5 and it's possible to summon more if you're lucky.

There are 60 different levels and 12 units, the difficulty increases quite soon after you reach the double digit levels, fortunately, there's an upgrade system you can utilize to improve unit stats, the effectiveness of items as well as the health of your 'base'(a wagon) and the amount of coins you receive when matching coin tiles. Upgrades do cost quite a bit, you can either buy more coins with real life money or slowly grind for upgrades(despite the grinding being rather slow, each 'match' can take seconds to minutes) and yes you can replay completed levels.

Quite a fun matching game but you have to be quick as there are time/match limits that vary with different levels.

While I do give Battle for Blood a thumbs up, I don't necessarily absolutely recommend this game.

The match 3 mechanic is an old, rather solid one, and combined with the upgrading system of the different units throughout the game, it is rather easy to get the hang of it. What is not so nice is the fact that it is nigh impossible to earn a lot of coins by repeating stages. Even more so, it will become incredibly difficult to make the necessary coins to affors the pricier upgrades. Hence, we are back at what we loathe - micro-transactions, to get the best out of the units, and even if you only want to do a couple of them.

And it isn't a particularly long game either. Battle for Blood only took me approximately 3.5 hours to really complete with one straight playthrough (aided by a micro-transaction, though it rather felt like a macro-transaction). As said, it is easy to play, but the coin-earning is a pain. And even with my love for grinding, I have to say: what you get from the already completed levels is far too little to really warrant leniency there.

reviewText:
You know how Puzzle Quest took match-3 games and added a level of interest to them by mixing the abstract puzzle-solving with some light RPG elements?

The short version is that you should play that instead.

Slightly longer version: This is another zero-effort mobile port, where you play Match 3 on a pretty small board, so you can summon up soldiers to do battle in a crappy Newgrounds-tier animation. It rapidly becomes a grindfest, so unless you're willing to shell out real money for in-game currency or repeat levels a bazillion times, it's hard to make progress. The problem is, it's not even a very good game. Match 3 has been done to death and it was hardly the world's most compelling idea in the first place. On the one hand it's free, but on the other, there are many many other things you can do for free that are more entertaining than this.

Also, your dudes fight skeleton warriors, which spray gouts of blood, because... reasons?

reviewText:
Battle for Blood is not the most diverse game out there but I have enjoyed playing it and there appears to be a lot of potential for improvement and expansion. I must say I was quite disappointed at the lack of variation in the new units you unlock, four soldier types the same except for higher stats on higher tier units, the same for the spearmen though I might give some variation credit for putting a horse under the second two you unlock. The rest was ok but I wanted more, there was no higher tier of archer which I was really looking forward to until I realised there wasn’t going to be one. Healers and wizards were good, though there could have been a bit more creativity put into them, how about wizards with some AoE fireballs and burn damage, overall there was a lot more thought put into the enemy units, some could even freeze stuff, fly, or brainwash your units. Last and definitely least is the peasants…. I don’t expect them to be spectacular but I’m not sure they count for anything as their weapon is a broom. What happened to the hoes!?!.... or shovels… or anything but brooms.

I downloaded it two days ago and just finished the last level so there is definitely something to be desired in the way of new content. I do like the % stat on the units and how it is used to determine what you can put into a level though I did think it would be nice to have the option to upgrade it, by all means make it super expensive but give that leeway to bump it up a little.

I am a big fan of token match games and all in all this was a very enjoyable one (if a bit short) and I was sucked in from the get go. I love that the game really is completely free and you can gain access to everything without spending a dollar. If you want a good, fun time killer then Battle for Blood is a good option and I would recommend it to anyone who likes these kinds of games.



Looking forward to the next content update.

reviewText:
NOTE: This game is Free to Play, so you lose nothing by playing it just for 30 minutes. Do not take my review seriously as you shouldn't with anyone else's due to that fact. See for your own eyes how good the game is.

Battle for Blood is a VERY obvious Mobile game port that doesn't seem to be any different from the original game, maknig the whole existence of this game on PC very debatable.

The game is basically a match-3-style game where matches summon units to attack enemies in a way that reminds me of Starjeweled, a Starcraft 2 custom game that is equally free to play.

Only here, there are different tiles and each tile type corresponds to a unit type, only unfortunately, they unlock as you complete the levels. The game would benefit from each unit type being rebalanced to allow this as it might add some more replayability, which given the fact that facebook, Kongregate, and even Steam itself offers far suprerior match-3 games...

The game doesn't really do well.

You can upgrade units, but ofcourse it doesn't matter too much as the game somewhat depends on RNG, hence being a match-3 game.

The Lives would work only on a phone where you can be notified when you get more, so you can play more, and the skills feel a bit lacking, the first being one to kill units on the screen, which is really all I used or got.

Altogether the game's art style does remind me of Castle Crashers, so there's that, and the soundtrack is decent, but altogether, the game doesn't stand out to me in any real way.

The game's mechanics don't work on a PC format too well, and it's obviously an unaltered mobile port.

If it cost money, you could bet that the reviews would be even harsher, so due to it being Free to Play, reviews don't really mean much, mine included.

I liked it, but once I got stuck, I immediately uninstalled and lost interest. I've played too many far better Match-3s on PC for this game to be at all relevant beyond the .6 hours I played.

This game gets a 5/10 with me. Just average, despite having a neat set of mechanics that would work better if they were improved upon for the PC version.

reviewText:
A very interesting little game, but can start getting frustrating the farther in you get.

This is a unique mix between a Bejeweled style tile-matching game and a tower defense-ish game.

You have to match tiles within the limited amount of turns and/or time to summon your units. This is where things can start getting frustrating. Sometimes you have to choose between passing the level or hopefully matching enough coin tiles to allow you to upgrade your units.

It's just frustrating enough to make a microtransaction for in-game currency tempting.

Natural grinders can push through it, but anyone else may start having issues with it.

Despite the need to really grind or fork out cash for enough gold to upgrade your units, I find this game enjoyable and would recommend it to those looking for a weird twist on a favorite genre.

reviewText:
PROS:
- free upgrade system
- huge combination varity
- two different ways to play
- no pay to win
- easy 100% Achievements

CONS:
- sound and music are just bad
- 3 stars are sometimes luck based
- no cloud save

RESULT:
It's one of the best free games on steam, because you don't spend any cent, if you don't want to. The game is completable without any pay to win. There are also two different game modes in the campain. In one mode you play with a limited amount of moves, in the other one with a time limit. The goal is to bring the enemy base down to ashes. Which is sometimes challenging, but most time a relaxing job. What units you use in the battle is up to you. In the beginning you will only have the amount of units you have to use. But later on, you can actually combine them as it pleases you. The way you upgrade your units can be strength, hp for example, but also something like critical hits and walking speed. The achievements are very easy to get. Some will might need longer, especially people that aren't that good in connect 3  games". But nothing is impossible
